description:
Aquibaculum sediminis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It was first isolated from sediment samples collected from a freshwater lake in China.

The cells of Aquibaculum sediminis are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and rod-shaped. They typically measure around 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.0-2.5 μm in length. The bacteria are facultatively anaerobic, meaning they can grow both in the presence and absence of oxygen.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Aquibaculum sediminis is most closely related to other members of the genus Aquibaculum, which are commonly found in aquatic environments. The genus Aquibaculum was first proposed in 2016 to accommodate a group of bacteria distinct from other Bacteroidetes genera.

Aquibaculum sediminis is capable of hydrolyzing a variety of complex organic compounds, including cellulose, xylan, and chitin, suggesting it plays a role in the degradation of plant and animal-derived materials in freshwater sediments. Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological significance and functional capabilities of this bacterial species.
